sn12.32:1.2.pli: Atha kho kaḷārakhattiyo bhikkhu yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn12.32:1.2.eng: Then the mendicant Kaḷāra the Aristocrat went up to Venerable Sāriputta and exchanged greetings with him.
sn12.32:1.2.comm: Kaḷāra the Aristocrat is otherwise unknown.

sn12.32:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kaḷārakhattiyo bhikkhu āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.32:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to him,

sn12.32:1.4.pli: “moḷiyaphagguno, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvatto”ti.
sn12.32:1.4.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, the mendicant Phagguna of the Top-Knot has resigned the training and returned to a lesser life.”
sn12.32:1.4.comm: For Phagguna of the Top-Knot, see note on SN 12.12:2.1.

sn12.32:1.5.pli: “Na hi nūna so āyasmā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye assāsamalatthā”ti.
sn12.32:1.5.eng: “That venerable mustn’t have gained any solace in this teaching and training.”

sn12.32:2.1.pli: “Tena hāyasmā sāriputto imasmiṃ dhammavinaye assāsaṃ patto”ti?
sn12.32:2.1.eng: “Well then, has Venerable Sāriputta found found in this teaching and training?”

sn12.32:5.1.pli: Atha kho kaḷārakhattiyo bhikkhu uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kaḷārakhattiyo bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.32:5.1.eng: Then Kaḷāra the Aristocrat went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn12.32:5.3.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmī”ti.
sn12.32:5.3.eng: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’”

sn12.32:6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
sn12.32:6.1.eng: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,

sn12.32:6.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena sāriputtaṃ āmantehi:
sn12.32:6.2.eng: “Please, monk, in my name tell Sāriputta that

sn12.32:6.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.32:6.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Sāriputta and said to him,

sn12.32:6.6.pli: “Evaṃ, āvuso”ti kho āyasmā sāriputto tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn12.32:6.6.eng: “Yes, reverend,” replied Sāriputta. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

sn12.32:6.7.eng: “Sāriputta, is it really true that you have declared enlightenment:

sn12.32:6.8.pli: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāmī”ti?
sn12.32:6.8.eng: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place”’?”

sn12.32:6.9.pli: “Na kho, bhante, etehi padehi etehi byañjanehi attho vutto”ti.
sn12.32:6.9.eng: “Sir, I did not state the matter in these words and phrases.”

sn12.32:6.10.pli: “Yena kenacipi, sāriputta, pariyāyena kulaputto aññaṃ byākaroti, atha kho byākataṃ byākatato daṭṭhabban”ti.
sn12.32:6.10.eng: “Sāriputta, no matter how a gentleman declares enlightenment, what he has declared should be regarded as such.”

sn12.32:6.11.eng: “Sir, did I not also say that

sn12.32:6.12.pli: ‘na kho, bhante, etehi padehi etehi byañjanehi attho vutto’”ti.
sn12.32:6.12.eng: I did not state the matter in these words and phrases?”

sn12.32:7.1.eng: “Sāriputta, suppose they were to ask you:

sn12.32:7.2.pli: ‘kathaṃ jānatā pana tayā, āvuso sāriputta, kathaṃ passatā aññā byākatā—
sn12.32:7.2.eng: ‘But Reverend Sāriputta, how have you known and seen so that you’ve declared enlightenment:

sn12.32:7.3.pli: khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmī’ti.
sn12.32:7.3.eng: “I understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”’

sn12.32:7.4.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭho tvaṃ, sāriputta, kinti byākareyyāsī”ti?

sn12.32:8.1.eng: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,

sn12.32:8.2.pli: ‘kathaṃ jānatā pana tayā, āvuso sāriputta, kathaṃ passatā aññā byākatā—

sn12.32:8.3.pli: khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmī’ti;

sn12.32:8.5.pli: ‘yaṃnidānā, āvuso, jāti, tassa nidānassa khayā khīṇasmiṃ khīṇāmhīti viditaṃ.
sn12.32:8.5.eng: ‘Reverends, when the source of rebirth ended, I knew “it is ended”.
sn12.32:8.5.comm: Read khīṇasmiṁ khīṇam’iti with PTS and BJT, paralleling the common phrase vimuttasmiṁ vimuttam’iti (SN 12.61:6.2). | The syntax here is convoluted: “With the end of that source which is the source of rebirth, I knew regarding that ending, ‘it is ended’.”

sn12.32:8.7.pli: khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmī’ti.
sn12.32:8.7.eng: I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’

sn12.32:8.8.eng: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”

sn12.32:9.1.eng: “But Sāriputta, suppose they were to ask you:

sn12.32:9.2.pli: ‘jāti panāvuso sāriputta, kiṃnidānā kiṃsamudayā kiṃjātikā kiṃpabhavā’ti?
sn12.32:9.2.eng: ‘But what is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of rebirth?’

sn12.32:9.3.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭho taṃ, sāriputta, kinti byākareyyāsī”ti?

sn12.32:9.4.eng: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,

sn12.32:9.5.pli: ‘jāti panāvuso sāriputta, kiṃnidānā kiṃsamudayā kiṃjātikā kiṃpabhavā’ti?

sn12.32:9.7.pli: ‘jāti kho, āvuso, bhavanidānā bhavasamudayā bhavajātikā bhavappabhavā’ti.
sn12.32:9.7.eng: ‘Continued existence is the source, origin, birthplace, and inception of rebirth.’

sn12.32:9.8.eng: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”

sn12.32:10.1.eng: “But Sāriputta, suppose they were to ask you:

sn12.32:10.2.pli: ‘bhavo panāvuso sāriputta, kiṃnidāno kiṃsamudayo kiṃjātiko kiṃpabhavo’ti?
sn12.32:10.2.eng: ‘What is the source of continued existence?’

sn12.32:10.3.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭho tvaṃ, sāriputta, kinti byākareyyāsī”ti?

sn12.32:10.4.eng: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,

sn12.32:10.5.pli: ‘bhavo panāvuso sāriputta, kiṃnidāno kiṃsamudayo kiṃjātiko kiṃpabhavo’ti?

sn12.32:10.7.pli: ‘bhavo kho, āvuso, upādānanidāno upādānasamudayo upādānajātiko upādānappabhavo’ti.
sn12.32:10.7.eng: ‘Grasping is the source of continued existence.’

sn12.32:10.8.eng: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”

sn12.32:11.1.eng: “But Sāriputta, suppose they were to ask you:

sn12.32:11.3.pli: sace pana taṃ, sāriputta, evaṃ puccheyyuṃ—
sn12.32:11.3.eng: But Sāriputta, suppose they were to ask you:

sn12.32:11.4.pli: taṇhā panāvuso sāriputta, kiṃnidānā kiṃsamudayā kiṃjātikā kiṃpabhavā’ti?

sn12.32:11.5.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭho tvaṃ, sāriputta, kinti byākareyyāsī”ti?

sn12.32:11.6.eng: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,

sn12.32:11.7.pli: ‘taṇhā panāvuso sāriputta, kiṃnidānā kiṃsamudayā kiṃjātikā kiṃpabhavā’ti?

sn12.32:11.9.pli: ‘taṇhā kho, āvuso, vedanānidānā vedanāsamudayā vedanājātikā vedanāpabhavā’ti.

sn12.32:11.10.eng: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”

sn12.32:12.1.eng: “But Sāriputta, suppose they were to ask you:

sn12.32:12.2.pli: ‘kathaṃ jānato pana te, āvuso sāriputta, kathaṃ passato yā vedanāsu nandī sā na upaṭṭhāsī’ti.
sn12.32:12.2.eng: ‘But how have you known and seen so that the relishing of feelings is no longer present?’
sn12.32:12.2.comm: The Buddha focuses in on the topic of feelings. The commentary explains this with reference to the Dīghanakhasutta (MN 74), which relates the occasion Sāriputta realized arahantship. The main topic, and the basis for Sāriputta’s insight, was feelings. The Buddha wanted to give Sāriputta the chance to highlight his special domain.

sn12.32:12.3.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭho tvaṃ, sāriputta, kinti byākareyyāsī”ti?

sn12.32:12.4.eng: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,

sn12.32:12.5.pli: ‘kathaṃ jānato pana te, āvuso sāriputta, kathaṃ passato yā vedanāsu nandī sā na upaṭṭhāsī’ti evaṃ puṭṭhohaṃ, bhante, evaṃ byākareyyaṃ:

sn12.32:12.8.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

sn12.32:12.9.pli: Imā kho, āvuso, tisso vedanā aniccā.

sn12.32:12.11.pli: viditaṃ, yā vedanāsu nandī sā na upaṭṭhāsī’ti.
sn12.32:12.11.eng: When I understood this, the relishing of feelings was no longer present.’

sn12.32:12.12.eng: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”

sn12.32:13.2.pli: Ayampi kho, sāriputta, pariyāyo, etasseva atthassa saṅkhittena veyyākaraṇāya:
sn12.32:13.2.eng: The same point may also be briefly explained in this way:

sn12.32:14.1.eng: But Sāriputta, suppose they were to ask you:

sn12.32:14.2.pli: ‘kathaṃ vimokkhā pana tayā, āvuso sāriputta, aññā byākatā—
sn12.32:14.2.eng: ‘But Reverend, how have you been liberated that you declare enlightenment:

sn12.32:14.3.pli: khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmī’ti?
sn12.32:14.3.eng: “I understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”?’

sn12.32:14.4.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭho tvaṃ, sāriputta, kinti byākareyyāsī”ti?

sn12.32:14.5.eng: “Sir, if they were to ask me this,

sn12.32:14.6.pli: ‘kathaṃ vimokkhā pana tayā, āvuso sāriputta, aññā byākatā—

sn12.32:14.7.pli: khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyāti pajānāmī’ti.

sn12.32:14.9.pli: ‘ajjhattaṃ vimokkhā khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sabbupādānakkhayā tathā sato viharāmi yathā sataṃ viharantaṃ āsavā nānussavanti, attānañca nāvajānāmī’ti.
sn12.32:14.9.eng: ‘Because of an inner release with the ending of all grasping, I live mindfully so that defilements don’t defile me and I don’t look down on myself.’
sn12.32:14.9.comm: Variants for nānussavanti are from the roots sav (“flow”) and sī (“lie”). Pali often couples verbs and nouns from the same root for emphasis, and this is probably the case here, “defilements don’t defile”.

sn12.32:14.10.eng: That’s how I’d answer such a question.”

sn12.32:15.2.pli: Ayampi kho sāriputta, pariyāyo etasseva atthassa saṅkhittena veyyākaraṇāya—
sn12.32:15.2.eng: The same point may also be briefly explained in this way:

sn12.32:15.3.pli: ye āsavā samaṇena vuttā tesvāhaṃ na kaṅkhāmi, te me pahīnāti na vicikicchāmī”ti.
sn12.32:15.3.eng: ‘I have no uncertainty regarding the defilements spoken of by the ascetic. I have no doubt that I’ve given them up.’”

sn12.32:15.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn12.32:15.5.pli: Idaṃ vatvā sugato uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ pāvisi.
sn12.32:15.5.eng: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

sn12.32:16.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto acirapakkantassa bhagavato bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn12.32:16.1.eng: Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sāriputta said to the mendicants,

sn12.32:16.2.pli: “pubbe appaṭisaṃviditaṃ maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā paṭhamaṃ pañhaṃ apucchi, tassa me ahosi dandhāyitattaṃ.
sn12.32:16.2.eng: “Reverends, the Buddha asked me the first question without letting me know beforehand, so I hesitated.
sn12.32:16.2.comm: Pubbe appaṭisaṁviditaṁ is an idiom elsewhere used when visiting someone “without letting them know beforehand” (MN 91:26.4, AN 5.50:4.7).

sn12.32:16.3.pli: Yato ca kho me, āvuso, bhagavā paṭhamaṃ pañhaṃ anumodi, tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, etadahosi—
sn12.32:16.3.eng: But when the Buddha agreed with my answer, I thought:

sn12.32:16.4.pli: divasañcepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi, divasampāhaṃ bhagavato etamatthaṃ byākareyyaṃ aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi.
sn12.32:16.4.eng: ‘If the Buddha were to question me all day on this matter in different words and ways, I could answer all day with different words and ways.

sn12.32:16.5.pli: Rattiñcepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi, rattimpāhaṃ bhagavato etamatthaṃ byākareyyaṃ aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi.
sn12.32:16.5.eng: If he were to question me all night,

sn12.32:16.6.pli: Rattindivaṃ cepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi, rattindivampāhaṃ bhagavato etamatthaṃ byākareyyaṃ aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi.

sn12.32:16.7.pli: Dve rattindivāni cepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya …pe…

sn12.32:16.9.pli: tīṇi rattindivāni cepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya …pe…

sn12.32:16.11.pli: cattāri rattindivāni cepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya …pe…

sn12.32:16.13.pli: pañca rattindivāni cepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya …pe…

sn12.32:16.15.pli: cha rattindivāni cepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya …pe…

sn12.32:16.17.pli: satta rattindivāni cepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi, satta rattindivānipāhaṃ bhagavato etamatthaṃ byākareyyaṃ aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehī”ti.
sn12.32:16.17.eng: or seven days and nights, I could answer in different words and ways for seven days and nights.’”

sn12.32:17.1.pli: Atha kho kaḷārakhattiyo bhikkhu uṭṭhāyāsanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kaḷārakhattiyo bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn12.32:17.1.eng: Then Kaḷāra the Aristocrat went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn12.32:17.2.eng: “Sir, Venerable Sāriputta has roared his lion’s roar!”

sn12.32:17.3.pli: pubbe appaṭisaṃviditaṃ maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā paṭhamaṃ pañhaṃ apucchi, tassa me ahosi dandhāyitattaṃ.
sn12.32:17.3.eng: (And he told the Buddha all that Sāriputta had said.)

sn12.32:17.4.pli: Yato ca kho me, āvuso, bhagavā paṭhamaṃ pañhaṃ anumodi, tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, etadahosi—

sn12.32:17.5.pli: divasañcepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi, divasampāhaṃ bhagavato etamatthaṃ byākareyyaṃ aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi;

sn12.32:17.13.pli: satta rattindivāni cepi maṃ bhagavā etamatthaṃ puccheyya aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi, satta rattindivānipāhaṃ bhagavato etamatthaṃ byākareyyaṃ aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehī”ti.

sn12.32:18.1.pli: “Sā hi, bhikkhu, sāriputtassa dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā, yassā dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā divasaṃ cepāhaṃ sāriputtaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyyaṃ aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi, divasampi me sāriputto etamatthaṃ byākareyya aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi.
sn12.32:18.1.eng: “Mendicant, Sāriputta has clearly penetrated the principle of the teachings, so that he could answer any questions I might ask him in different words and ways up to the seventh day and night.”

sn12.32:18.2.pli: Rattiṃ cepāhaṃ sāriputtaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyyaṃ aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi, rattimpi me sāriputto etamatthaṃ byākareyya …pe…

sn12.32:18.3.pli: rattindivaṃ cepāhaṃ sāriputtaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyyaṃ, rattindivampi me sāriputto etamatthaṃ byākareyya …

sn12.32:18.4.pli: dve rattindivāni cepāhaṃ sāriputtaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyyaṃ, dve rattindivānipi me sāriputto etamatthaṃ byākareyya …

sn12.32:18.5.pli: tīṇi rattindivāni cepāhaṃ sāriputtaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyyaṃ, tīṇi rattindivānipi me sāriputto etamatthaṃ byākareyya …

sn12.32:18.6.pli: cattāri rattindivāni cepāhaṃ sāriputtaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyyaṃ, cattāri rattindivānipi me sāriputto etamatthaṃ byākareyya …

sn12.32:18.7.pli: pañca rattindivāni cepāhaṃ sāriputtaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyyaṃ, pañca rattindivānipi me sāriputto etamatthaṃ byākareyya …

sn12.32:18.8.pli: cha rattindivāni cepāhaṃ sāriputtaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyyaṃ, cha rattindivānipi me sāriputto etamatthaṃ byākareyya …

sn12.32:18.9.pli: satta rattindivāni cepāhaṃ sāriputtaṃ etamatthaṃ puccheyyaṃ aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehi, satta rattindivānipi me sāriputto etamatthaṃ byākareyya aññamaññehi padehi aññamaññehi pariyāyehī”ti.

sn12.33:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach forty-four grounds for knowledge.
sn12.33:1.2.comm: “Grounds for knowledge” (ñāṇavatthu) are those things whose understanding leads to liberation.

sn12.33:1.3.pli: taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn12.33:1.3.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn12.33:1.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn12.33:2.1.eng: “And what are the forty-four grounds for knowledge?

sn12.33:2.2.pli: Jarāmaraṇe ñāṇaṃ, jarāmaraṇasamudaye ñāṇaṃ, jarāmaraṇanirodhe ñāṇaṃ, jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ;
sn12.33:2.2.eng: Knowledge of old age and death, knowledge of the origin of old age and death, knowledge of the cessation of old age and death, and knowledge of the practice that leads to the cessation of old age and death.

sn12.33:2.3.pli: jātiyā ñāṇaṃ, jātisamudaye ñāṇaṃ, jātinirodhe ñāṇaṃ, jātinirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ;

sn12.33:2.4.pli: bhave ñāṇaṃ, bhavasamudaye ñāṇaṃ, bhavanirodhe ñāṇaṃ, bhavanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ;

sn12.33:2.5.pli: upādāne ñāṇaṃ, upādānasamudaye ñāṇaṃ, upādānanirodhe ñāṇaṃ, upādānanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ;

sn12.33:2.6.pli: taṇhāya ñāṇaṃ, taṇhāsamudaye ñāṇaṃ, taṇhānirodhe ñāṇaṃ, taṇhānirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ;

sn12.33:2.7.pli: vedanāya ñāṇaṃ, vedanāsamudaye ñāṇaṃ, vedanānirodhe ñāṇaṃ, vedanānirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ;

sn12.33:2.9.eng: Knowledge of the six sense fields …

sn12.33:2.12.pli: saṅkhāresu ñāṇaṃ, saṅkhārasamudaye ñāṇaṃ, saṅkhāranirodhe ñāṇaṃ, saṅkhāranirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṃ.
sn12.33:2.12.eng: Knowledge of choices, knowledge of the origin of choices, knowledge of the cessation of choices, and knowledge of the practice that leads to the cessation of choices.

sn12.33:2.13.eng: These are called the forty-four grounds for knowledge.

sn12.33:3.1.eng: And what is old age and death?

sn12.33:3.2.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jarā jīraṇatā khaṇḍiccaṃ pāliccaṃ valittacatā āyuno saṃhāni indriyānaṃ paripāko,
sn12.33:3.2.eng: The old age, decrepitude, broken teeth, grey hair, wrinkly skin, diminished vitality, and failing faculties of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

sn12.33:3.4.pli: Yā tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhā tamhā sattanikāyā cuti cavanatā bhedo antaradhānaṃ maccu maraṇaṃ kālakiriyā khandhānaṃ bhedo kaḷevarassa nikkhepo.
sn12.33:3.4.eng: The passing away, passing on, disintegration, demise, mortality, death, decease, breaking up of the aggregates, and laying to rest of the corpse of the various sentient beings in the various orders of sentient beings.

sn12.33:3.6.eng: Such is old age, and such is death.

sn12.33:3.7.eng: This is called old age and death.

sn12.33:4.1.eng: Rebirth is the origin of old age and death.

sn12.33:4.2.eng: When rebirth ceases, old age and death cease.

sn12.33:4.3.pli: ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn12.33:4.3.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of old age and death is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn12.33:4.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn12.33:5.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ jarāmaraṇaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, idamassa dhamme ñāṇaṃ.
sn12.33:5.1.eng: A noble disciple understands old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation. This is their knowledge of the teaching.
sn12.33:5.1.comm: Dhamme ñāṇaṁ is the knowledge of the principles of the teaching that are apparent in the present life (cf. diṭṭheva dhamme). It contrasts with anvaye ñāṇaṁ, knowledge inferred to the past and future. The pair, along with knowledge of others’ minds and conventional knowledge, are also at DN 33:1.11.103, DN 34:1.5.35, and Vb 16:307.1. The two forms of knowledge are illustrated in the narrative of Vipassī (DN 14:1.36.1).

sn12.33:5.2.pli: So iminā dhammena diṭṭhena viditena akālikena pattena pariyogāḷhena atītānāgate nayaṃ neti.
sn12.33:5.2.eng: With this teaching that is seen, understood, immediately attained, and fathomed, they apply the method to the past and future.
sn12.33:5.2.comm: The same phrase is found in SN 42.11:2.9, which likewise discusses what is presently observable and what is inferred. Similar terms also describe one who realizes the Dhamma as a stream-enterer (MN 56:18.8).

sn12.33:6.1.pli: Ye kho keci atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā jarāmaraṇaṃ abbhaññaṃsu, jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ abbhaññaṃsu, jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ abbhaññaṃsu, jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abbhaññaṃsu, sabbete evameva abbhaññaṃsu, seyyathāpāhaṃ etarahi.
sn12.33:6.1.eng: Whatever ascetics and brahmins in the past directly knew old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation, all of them directly knew these things in exactly the same way that I do now.

sn12.33:7.1.pli: Yepi hi keci anāgatamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā jarāmaraṇaṃ abhijānissanti, jarāmaraṇasamudayaṃ abhijānissanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhaṃ abhijānissanti, jarāmaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhijānissanti, sabbete evameva abhijānissanti, seyyathāpāhaṃ etarahīti.
sn12.33:7.1.eng: Whatever ascetics and brahmins in the future will directly know old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation, all of them will directly know these things in exactly the same way that I do now.

sn12.33:7.2.comm: This knowledge “inferred” from the principles of the teaching allows Sāriputta to state that there has never been, nor ever will be, anyone more enlightened than the Buddha, even though he cannot read the minds of all the Buddhas (SN 47.12:6.2, DN 16:1.17.8, DN 28:2.2). Pasenadi likewise “infers from the teaching” that the Buddha is awakened due to his behavior and that of the Saṅgha; since Pasenadi was not enlightened, this is not a special faculty of awakening (MN 89:13.17). Nonetheless, a fool like Sunakkhatta cannot infer in this way (MN 12:5.1). In all of these cases, dhamma has the primary meaning of “teaching”, but in particular, the principles of the teaching that are observable (see especially DN 28:2.14).

sn12.33:8.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa imāni dve ñāṇāni parisuddhāni honti pariyodātāni—
sn12.33:8.1.eng: A noble disciple has purified and cleansed these two knowledges—

sn12.33:8.2.eng: knowledge of the teaching and inferential knowledge.

sn12.33:8.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako diṭṭhisampanno itipi, dassanasampanno itipi, āgato imaṃ saddhammaṃ itipi, passati imaṃ saddhammaṃ itipi, sekkhena ñāṇena samannāgato itipi, sekkhāya vijjāya samannāgato itipi, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno itipi, ariyo nibbedhikapañño itipi, amatadvāraṃ āhacca tiṭṭhati itipīti.
sn12.33:8.3.eng: When a noble disciple has done this, they’re one who is called ‘one accomplished in view’, ‘one accomplished in vision’, ‘one who has come to the true teaching’, ‘one who sees this true teaching’, ‘one endowed with a trainee’s knowledge’, ‘one who has entered the stream of the teaching’, ‘a noble one with penetrative wisdom’, and also ‘one who stands pressing against the door to freedom from death’.

sn12.33:9.7.eng: And what are the six sense fields? …

sn12.33:9.8.eng: And what are name and form? …

sn12.33:9.11.eng: There are three kinds of choices.

sn12.33:9.12.eng: Choices by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn12.33:10.1.eng: Ignorance is the origin of choices.

sn12.33:10.3.pli: ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saṅkhāranirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn12.33:10.3.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of choices is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn12.33:10.4.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn12.33:11.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako evaṃ saṅkhāre pajānāti, evaṃ saṅkhārasamudayaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saṅkhāranirodhaṃ pajānāti, evaṃ saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ pajānāti, idamassa dhamme ñāṇaṃ.
sn12.33:11.1.eng: A noble disciple understands choices, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation. This is their knowledge of the teaching.

sn12.33:11.2.pli: So iminā dhammena diṭṭhena viditena akālikena pattena pariyogāḷhena atītānāgate nayaṃ neti.
sn12.33:11.2.eng: With this teaching that is seen, understood, immediately attained, and fathomed, they apply the method to the past and future.

sn12.33:12.1.pli: Ye kho keci atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā saṅkhāre abbhaññaṃsu, saṅkhārasamudayaṃ abbhaññaṃsu, saṅkhāranirodhaṃ abbhaññaṃsu, saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abbhaññaṃsu, sabbete evameva abbhaññaṃsu, seyyathāpāhaṃ etarahi.
sn12.33:12.1.eng: Whatever ascetics and brahmins in the past directly knew choices, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation, all of them directly knew these things in exactly the same way that I do now.

sn12.33:13.1.pli: Ye hipi keci anāgatamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā saṅkhāre abhijānissanti, saṅkhārasamudayaṃ abhijānissanti, saṅkhāranirodhaṃ abhijānissanti, saṅkhāranirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ abhijānissanti, sabbete evameva abhijānissanti, seyyathāpāhaṃ etarahi.
sn12.33:13.1.eng: Whatever ascetics and brahmins in the future will directly know choices, their origin, their cessation, and the practice that leads to their cessation, all of them will directly know these things in exactly the same way that I do now.

sn12.33:14.1.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa imāni dve ñāṇāni parisuddhāni honti pariyodātāni—
sn12.33:14.1.eng: A noble disciple has purified and cleansed these two knowledges—

sn12.33:14.2.eng: knowledge of the teaching and inferential knowledge.

sn12.33:14.3.pli: Ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako diṭṭhisampanno itipi, dassanasampanno itipi, āgato imaṃ saddhammaṃ itipi, passati imaṃ saddhammaṃ itipi, sekkhena ñāṇena samannāgato itipi, sekkhāya vijjāya samannāgato itipi, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno itipi, ariyo nibbedhikapañño itipi, amatadvāraṃ āhacca tiṭṭhati itipī”ti.
sn12.33:14.3.eng: When a noble disciple has done this, they’re one who is called ‘one accomplished in view’, ‘one accomplished in vision’, ‘one who has come to the true teaching’, ‘one who sees this true teaching’, ‘one endowed with a trainee’s knowledge’, ‘one who has entered the stream of the teaching’, ‘a noble one with penetrative wisdom’, and also ‘one who stands pressing against the door to freedom from death’.”

sn12.34:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach seventy-seven grounds for knowledge.

sn12.34:1.3.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn12.34:1.3.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn12.34:1.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn12.34:2.1.eng: “And what are the seventy-seven grounds for knowledge?

sn12.34:2.2.eng: The knowledge that rebirth is a requirement for old age and death,

sn12.34:2.3.eng: and the knowledge that when rebirth doesn’t exist, there is no old age and death.

sn12.34:2.4.pli: atītampi addhānaṃ jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇanti ñāṇaṃ, asati jātiyā natthi jarāmaraṇanti ñāṇaṃ;
sn12.34:2.4.eng: Also regarding the past: the knowledge that rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, and the knowledge that when rebirth doesn’t exist, there is no old age and death.

sn12.34:2.5.pli: anāgatampi addhānaṃ jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇanti ñāṇaṃ, asati jātiyā natthi jarāmaraṇanti ñāṇaṃ;
sn12.34:2.5.eng: Also regarding the future: the knowledge that rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, and the knowledge that when rebirth doesn’t exist, there is no old age and death.

sn12.34:2.6.pli: yampissa taṃ dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṃ tampi khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhammanti ñāṇaṃ.
sn12.34:2.6.eng: And also their knowledge that even this knowledge of the stability of natural principles is liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.

sn12.34:3.1.eng: The knowledge that continued existence is a requirement for rebirth …

sn12.34:3.10.pli: avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārāti ñāṇaṃ, asati avijjāya natthi saṅkhārāti ñāṇaṃ;
sn12.34:3.10.eng: The knowledge that ignorance is a requirement for choices, and the knowledge that when ignorance doesn’t exist, there are no choices.

sn12.34:3.11.pli: atītampi addhānaṃ avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārāti ñāṇaṃ, asati avijjāya natthi saṅkhārāti ñāṇaṃ;
sn12.34:3.11.eng: Also regarding the past: the knowledge that ignorance is a requirement for choices, and the knowledge that when ignorance doesn’t exist, there are no choices.

sn12.34:3.12.pli: anāgatampi addhānaṃ avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārāti ñāṇaṃ, asati avijjāya natthi saṅkhārāti ñāṇaṃ;
sn12.34:3.12.eng: Also regarding the future: the knowledge that ignorance is a requirement for choices, and the knowledge that when ignorance doesn’t exist, there are no choices.

sn12.34:3.13.pli: yampissa taṃ dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṃ tampi khayadhammaṃ vayadhammaṃ virāgadhammaṃ nirodhadhammanti ñāṇaṃ.
sn12.34:3.13.eng: And also their knowledge that even this knowledge of the stability of natural principles is liable to end, vanish, fade away, and cease.
sn12.34:3.13.comm: The natural principles themselves do not disappear, for it is always true to describe the world as suffering and impermanent. But the knowledge of that is impermanent, for it is a conscious state and will pass away when the enlightened being passes away.

sn12.34:3.14.eng: These are called the seventy-seven grounds for knowledge.”
